docs.title: Installation¶
docs.body: Install the package using pip.

docs.title: Installation¶
docs.body: pip install jinjax

docs.title: Usage¶
docs.body: The first thing you must do in your app is to create a "catalog" of components. This is the object that manage the components and its global settings. Then, you add to the catalog the folder(s) with your components.

docs.title: Usage¶
docs.body:
from jinjax import Catalog

catalog = Catalog()
catalog.add_folder("myapp/components")

docs.title: Usage¶
docs.body: You use the catalog to render a parent component from your views:

docs.title: Usage¶
docs.body:
def myview():
  ...
  return catalog.render(
    "ComponentName",
    title="Lorem ipsum",
    message="Hello",
  )

docs.title: Components¶
docs.body: The components are .jinja files with snippets of template code (HTML or otherwise). They can also call other components.

docs.title: Components names¶
docs.body: The components must start with an uppercase. I recommend that you use PascalCase names, like Python classes.

docs.title: Components names¶
docs.body: For example, if the filename es PersonForm.jinja, the name of the component is PersonForm and can be used like <PersonForm> ... </PersonForm> or just <PersonForm />.

docs.title: Components names¶
docs.body: You can organize your components in subfolders, using a dot (.) to indicate a subfolder. For example, you would call a components/Person/Form.jinja components as <Person.Form> ... </Person.Form>

docs.title: Components arguments¶
docs.body: A component can only use data you pass it explicitly and global variables. To declare what arguments it takes, begin the file with a {#def ... #} Jinja comment. Some of these arguments might have a default value (making them optional):

docs.title: Components arguments¶
docs.body:
{#def title, message='Hi' #}

<h1>{{ title }}</h1>
<div>{{ message }}. This is my component</div>

docs.title: Jinja¶
docs.body: JinjaX use Jinja internally to render the templates. You can add your own global variables and functions, filters, tests, and Jinja extensions when creating the catalog:

docs.title: Jinja¶
docs.body:
from jinjax import Catalog

catalog = Catalog(
    globals={ ... },
    filters={ ... },
    tests={ ... },
    extensions=[ ... ],
)

docs.title: Jinja¶
docs.body: or afterwards.

docs.title: Jinja¶
docs.body:
catalog.jinja_env.globals.update({ ... })
catalog.jinja_env.filters.update({ ... })
catalog.jinja_env.tests.update({ ... })
catalog.jinja_env.extensions.extend([ ... ])

docs.title: Jinja¶
docs.body: The "do" extension is enabled by default, so you can write things like:

docs.title: Jinja¶
docs.body: {% do attrs.set(class="btn", disabled=True) %}

docs.title: Reusing an existing Jinja Environment¶
docs.body: You can also reuse an existing Jinja Environment, for example:

docs.title: Flask:¶
docs.body:
app = Flask(__name__)

# Here we add the flask Jinja globals, filters, etc. like `url_for()`
catalog = jinjax.Catalog(jinja_env=app.jinja_env)

docs.title: Django:¶
docs.body: First, configure Jinja in setting.py and jinja_env.py)

docs.title: Django:¶
docs.body: To have a separate "components" folder for shared components and also have "components" subfolder at each django app level

docs.title: Django:¶
docs.body:
import jinjax
from jinja2.loaders import FileSystemLoader

def environment(loader: FileSystemLoader, **options):
    env = Environment(loader=loader, **options)

    ...

    env.add_extension(jinjax.JinjaX)
    catalog = jinjax.Catalog(jinja_env=env)

    catalog.add_folder("components")
    for dir in loader.searchpath:
        catalog.add_folder(os.path.join(dir, "components"))

    return env

docs.title: Components¶
docs.body: The components are .jinja files with snippets of template code. They look like a fragment of a regular Jinja template – and they could be – except for the optional special comments at the beginning of the file.

docs.title: Component Arguments¶
docs.body: More often than not, a component takes one or more arguments to render. Every argument must be declared at the beginning of the component with {#def arguments #}. The syntax is very similar to how you declare the arguments of a python function:

docs.title: Component Arguments¶
docs.body: components/Form.jinja

docs.title: Component Arguments¶
docs.body:
{#def action, method='post', multipart=False #}

<form method="{{ method }}" action="{{ action }}"
  {%- if multipart %} enctype="multipart/form-data"{% endif %}
>
  {{ content }}
</form>

docs.title: Component Arguments¶
docs.body: In this example, the component takes three arguments: "action", "method", and "multipart". The last two have a default value, so they are optional, but the first one doesn't. That means it must be passed a value when rendering the component.

docs.title: Component Arguments¶
docs.body: So all of these are valid forms to use this component:

docs.title: Component Arguments¶
docs.body:
<Form action="/new"> ... </Form>
<Form action="/new" method="PATCH"> ... </Form>
<Form multipart={False} action="/new"> ... </Form>

docs.title: Component Arguments¶
docs.body: The values of the declared arguments can be used in the template as values with the same name.

docs.title: Components with content¶
docs.body: There is actually always an extra implicit argument: the content inside the component. This could be anything: text, HTML, and/or other components; but the component recieves it already rendered to a string.

docs.title: Components with content¶
docs.body:
{# Component with content #}
<Name _arguments_ > ...content here... </Name>

{# Self-closing component, `content` is an empty string #}
<Name _arguments_ />

docs.title: Components with content¶
docs.body: A great use case of the content is to make layout components:

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body: If you pass arguments not declared in a component, those are not discarded, but rather collected in a attrs object that can render these extra arguments calling attrs.render()

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body: For example, this component:

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body: components/Card.jinja

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body:
{#def title #}

<div {{ attrs.render() }}>
  <h1>{{ title }}</h1>
  {{ content }}
</div>

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body: Called as:

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body:
<Card title="Products" class="mb-10" open>
bla
</Card>

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body: Will be rendered as:

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body:
<div class="mb-10" open>
  <h1>Products</h1>
  bla
</div>

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body: You can add or remove arguments before rendering them using the other methods of the attrs object. For example:

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body:
{#def title #}

{% do attrs.set(id="mycard") -%}

<div {{ attrs.render() }}>
  <h1>{{ title }}</h1>
  {{ content }}
</div>

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body: Or directly in the attrs.render() call:

docs.title: Extra Arguments¶
docs.body:
{#def title #}

<div {{ attrs.render(id="mycard") }}>
  <h1>{{ title }}</h1>
  {{ content }}
</div>

docs.title: .render(name=value, ...)¶
docs.body: Renders the current attributes and properties as a string. Any attributes/properties you pass to this method, will be used to call attrs.set(**kwargs) before rendering.

docs.title: .render(name=value, ...)¶
docs.body:
• Pass a name and a value to set an attribute (e.g. type="text")
  • Use True as value to set a property (e.g. disabled)
  • Use False to remove an attribute or property

docs.title: .render(name=value, ...)¶
docs.body: The underscores in the names will be translated automatically to dashes, so aria_selected becomes the attribute aria-selected.

docs.title: .render(name=value, ...)¶
docs.body: The current attribute/property are overwritten except if is "class" or "classes". In those cases, the new classes are appended to the old ones instead of replacing them.

docs.title: .render(name=value, ...)¶
docs.body: To provide consistent output, the attributes and properties are sorted by name and rendered like this: <sorted attributes> + <sorted properties>.

docs.title: .render(name=value, ...)¶
docs.body:
<button {{ attrs.render() }}>
  {{ content }}
</button>

docs.title: Adding CSS and JS¶
docs.body: Your components might need custom styles or custom JavaScript for many reasons. Instead of using global stylesheet or script files, writing assets for each individual component has several advantages:

docs.title: Adding CSS and JS¶
docs.body:
• Portability: You can copy a component from one project to another, knowing it will keep working as expected.
  • Performance: Only load the CSS and JS that you need on each page. Also, the browser will already have cached the assets of the components for other pages that use them.
  • Simple testing: You can test the JS of a component independently from others.

docs.title: Auto-loading assets¶
docs.body: JinjaX searches for .css and .js files with the same name as your component in the same folder and automatically adds them to the list of assets that will be included in the page. For example, if your component is components/common/Form.jinja, both components/common/Form.css and components/common/Form.js will be added to the list, but only if those files exist.

docs.title: Manually declaring assets¶
docs.body: In addition to auto-loading assets, the CSS and/or the JS of a component can be declared in the metadata header with {#css ... #} and {#js ... #}.

docs.title: Manually declaring assets¶
docs.body:
{#css lorem.css, ipsum.css #}
{#js foo.js, bar.js #}

docs.title: Manually declaring assets¶
docs.body:
• The file paths must be relative to the root of your components catalog (e.g., components/form.js) or absolute (e.g., http://example.com/styles.css).
  • Multiple assets must be separated by commas.
  • Only one {#css ... #} and one {#js ... #} tag is allowed per component at most, but both are optional.

docs.title: Global assets¶
docs.body: The best practice is to store both CSS and JS files of the component within the same folder. Doing this has several advantages, including easier component reuse in other projects, improved code readability, and simplified debugging.

docs.title: Global assets¶
docs.body: However, there are instances when you may need to rely on global CSS or JS files, such as third-party libraries. In such cases, you can specify these dependencies in the component's metadata using URLs that start with either "/", "http://," or "https://."

docs.title: Global assets¶
docs.body: When you do this, JinjaX will render them as is; instead of prepending them with the component's prefix like it normally does.

docs.title: Global assets¶
docs.body: For example, this code:

docs.title: Global assets¶
docs.body:
{#css foo.css, bar.css, /static/bootstrap.min.css #}
{#js http://example.com/cdn/moment.js, bar.js  #}

{{ catalog.render_assets() }}

docs.title: Global assets¶
docs.body: will be rendered as this HTML output:

docs.title: Global assets¶
docs.body:
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/foo.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/bar.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/bootstrap.min.css">
<script type="module" src="http://example.com/cdn/moment.js"></script>
<script type="module" src="/static/components/bar.js"></script>

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body: The catalog will collect all CSS and JS file paths from the components used on a "page" render on the catalog.collected_css and catalog.collected_js lists.

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body: For example, after rendering this component:

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body: components/MyPage.jinja

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body:
{#css mypage.css #}
{#js mypage.js #}

<Layout title="My page">
  <Card>
    <CardBody>
      <h1>Lizard</h1>
      <p>The Iguana is a type of lizard</p>
    </CardBody>
    <CardActions>
      <Button size="small">Share</Button>
    </CardActions>
  </Card>
</Layout>

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body: Assuming the Card, and Button components declare CSS assets, this will be the state of the collected_css list:

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body:
catalog.collected_css
['mypage.css', 'card.css', 'button.css']

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body: You can add the <link> and <script> tags to your page automatically by calling catalog.render_assets() like this:

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body: components/Layout.jinja

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body:
{#def title #}

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
  <meta charset="utf-8">
  <title>{{ title }}</title>
  {{ catalog.render_assets() }}
</head>
<body>
  {{ content }}
</body>
</html>

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body: The variable will be rendered as:

docs.title: Including assets in your pages¶
docs.body:
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/mypage.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/card.css">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="/static/components/button.css">
<script type="module" src="/static/components/mypage.js"></script>
<script type="module" src="/static/components/card.js"></script>
<script type="module" src="/static/components/button.js"></script>

docs.title: Middleware¶
docs.body: The tags above will not work at all if your application can't return the content of those files, and right now it can't.

docs.title: Middleware¶
docs.body: For that reason, JinjaX includes a WSGI middleware that will process those URLs if you add it to your application.

docs.title: Middleware¶
docs.body:
from flask import Flask
from jinjax import Catalog

app = Flask(__name__)

# Here we add the Flask Jinja globals, filters, etc., like `url_for()`
catalog = jinjax.Catalog(jinja_env=app.jinja_env)

catalog.add_folder("myapp/components")

app.wsgi_app = catalog.get_middleware(
    app.wsgi_app,
    autorefresh=app.debug,
)

docs.title: Middleware¶
docs.body: The middleware uses the battle-tested Whitenoise library and will only respond to the .css and .js files inside the component(s) folder(s). You can configure it to also return files with other extensions. For example:

docs.title: Middleware¶
docs.body: catalog.get_middleware(app, allowed_ext=[".css", ".js", ".svg", ".png"])

docs.title: Middleware¶
docs.body: Be aware that, if you use this option, get_middleware() must be called after all folders are added.

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body: The styles of your components will not be auto-scoped. This means the styles of a component can affect other components, and, likewise, it will be affected by global styles or the styles of other components.

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body: To protect yourself against that, always add a custom class to the root element(s) of your component and use it to scope the rest of the component styles.

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body: You can even use this syntax now supported by all modern web browsers:

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body:
.Parent {
  .foo { ... }
  .bar { ... }
}

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body: The code above will be interpreted as

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body:
.Parent .foo { ... }
.Parent .bar { ... }

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body: Example:

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body: components/Card.jinja

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body:
{#css card.css #}

<div {{ attrs.render(class="Card") }}>
  <h1>My Card</h1>
  ...
</div>

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body: components/card.css

docs.title: CSS Scoping¶
docs.body:
/* 🚫 DO NOT do this */
h1 { font-size: 2em; }
h2 { font-size: 1.5em; }
a { color: blue; }

/* 👍 DO THIS instead */
.Card {
  h1 { font-size: 2em; }
  h2 { font-size: 1.5em; }
  a { color: blue; }
}

/* 👍 Or this */
.Card h1 { font-size: 2em; }
.Card h2 { font-size: 1.5em; }
.Card a { color: blue; }
